The people don't use gensets at home because:	1) noisy	2) poor Voltage + frequency control	3) low best case inefficiency	4) inefficient over range	5) poor maintenance duty cycle	6) Much higher costs than grid	7) Low night loads 	8) No other purpose	9) fuel access.
When solar thermal power is used, the low end efficiency below 1 KW is not important.  In most cases with NH3 storage, excess power from solar is used to make NH3, and the power is well above 1 KW.
By having several, at least three, motors + electric generators, all working together, a "micro" grid is formed that allows a wide range of efficient power generation.  Below 1 KW, it becomes difficult and a small battery/inverter can be used for critical electronic devices.
Both the old engine and electric generator have a range that they are efficient at.  Total efficiency is the multiplication of both.  The grid takes care of this my adding and subtracting engines, and so does my technology, in part.  A 20 kw genset is made up of several, not one.
The problem of efficiency in old Diesel/Otto engine generators is partly due to the constant RPM nature of the grid.  You can't shift gears easily to allow the engine to speed up and slow down to vary power.  The electric generator is also part of the problem. Range of efficiency
An old design genset can run you over $1.1/kwh, even $2 at low power settings. This is around 10 times more than grid.  But my motor can run on NH3 for 4 c/kwh fuel.  No worries about black outs.  This means fuels supplies will last too.  Why be on grid?  Good question....
My motor is at 60-75% and not 3-6% or less with the 16 hp genset.  		If fuel (gasoline) costs $2.3/gal at 6% efficiency it costs $1.13/kwh for fuel.  		At 20%, 2.3/33.7/.2= 34 c/kwh.  		At 75%?  2.3/33.7/.75=9 c/kwh.  		At $1 NH3 /33.7/.75=4 c/kwh....&gt;
But a small Honda generator can't start refrigerators and compressor motors.  Too much peak spike power.  The grid provides an infinite inertia to overcome the spike loads.  A small Honda generator does not.  To run your house you get a 16 hp genset that runs at 1-3 hp.  ineff
You have two things.  Power pulse and lowest idle and power speed.  In six cylinder motor, idle is 800 and min run is around 1000-1200.  1000/5000 x 200 hp x .5 throttle = 20 hp.  But you only need 1-5 hp, say.  Big engine being strangled for small power.  Hence a Honda generator
You ask, why can't I run my Buick engine and generate power?  Because a Buick engine is designed WRONG and is very inefficient at low power (2-5%?).  If peak power at 5000 rpm is 200 hp at 1500 rpm 60 hp.  1/2 throttle is 30 hp.  You only need 1-6 hp, not 30.  BSFC goes up 3-4 x.
By having some spare fuel (propane, gasoline, Diesel, 100 LL, Jet A) on hand, you can keep the electrical power on via the car running for as long as the fuel flows. You can then move to different areas and help people with emergency power if needed, for example.
With the car generator (various sizes....) you could also run any building that needs power via the power in the car.  Use the car fuel to run car engine + generator in car to  power building at less than grid rates.  No grid black out risks.  No spoiled food.  No hassles.
Moreover, if NH3 runs out, you can get propane, gasoline, Diesel, Ethanol, Jet A or even 100 LL if the stuff is really "hitting the fan."  All your neighbors are without power and you are running for less than grid rates.  Be grid connected or independent from grid.  Your choice.
This engine system allows uninterrupted power without the need for battery systems that have only short term power (minutes?)  With this system, the grid power can be out indefinitely (months?) and still function 100% normally without a 1/2 sine drop.  No black out risks at all.
For example, a Best Buy locally had issues with power dropping at the builidng they were leasing where power was cheaper.  They had to move to a new location due to the need to restart all their computers when 1/2 sine wave dropped. This cost more money to have secure power....&gt;
If you research or look into "back up" generators you soon realize they are very expensive and complex due to the characteristics of the Diesel engine used to drive the generator.  This ability to not "drop a half sine wave" is key to continuous uninterrupted power.
The key to this solution is the characteristic of the motor of no delay in response, not found in any IC engine.  This allows instant response to a torque demand, and no hesitation starting like you have with Diesel/Otto engines.  This allows for "electric" like torque response.
It takes a little power to run all three generators (not motor!) at synchronous speeds, ready to produce power.  The motor to torque a generator can be off/on instantly while the generators keeps spinning.  If the loads are low, just limit to none or just one generator in spin.
If you want to constantly make 3x power instead of only a spike load, you then run the other two generators for a total of 27 hp or 20 KW or max to grid for house installation.  It can spike to 60KW for short duration only.  To vary from 1-20 KW have all gens synchronized...&gt;
If you want to vary the power from 1-6 KW, only have one motor and generator on.  If you want to be able to take a spike load, the generator can produce short term power of 3x without spin needs.  The motor can vary by 3x (6-18 KW) of efficient torque x for a short duration.
Spin allows for large variations in power instantly.  The generator is alreay synchronized to the master and ready to produce power instantly.  The motors can be shut off, but can still respond instantly to torque the spin generator due to the design, unlike a Diesel/Otto engine. https://t.co/tPCC9QKWRa
By dividing up the electrical generators, which give a pure sine wave and not junk inverter waves, into three smaller generators, the efficiency can be maintained across the entire range of the additive generators.  During low power, "spin" is still required, just like grid does.
With 44,000 hrs on each motor and three motors, you would get 15 years   if you only ran 1 of three motors for house power at grid speed.  900 RPM would be 9 HP or 6.7 kw, enough to run house.  Other motors off and second generator ran as "spin" reserve ready for spike loads.
If you used engine in house at 900 RPM, you would get around 44,000 hrs or 5 years between "overhauls" if ran constantly.  If you make solar NH3 then the 900 rpm can go up much higher to get more power if not connected to grid.  Remember, three motors work, one grid, two NH3. https://t.co/twW95oCZiv

Why tandem seating in air taxi?  Side by side is too intimate for strangers.  Tandem gives you 33 wide x 36 L x 48+ high space you can isolate yourself from other ride share persons you don't know.  Buy a space on airplane.  Have window on each side, and air temp and Ipad =Chill.

If the road tax should be 17 c/kwh for a Tesla roadster and PV panel is 5 cents (actually 15 c/kwh, but lets follow the claims) that make tax and fuel 22 c/kwh.  Add in 12 cent/kwh for battery use and you have 34 c/kwh.  Notice 17 (road tax) is 1/2 of 34.  34x33.7 = $11.46/gal e.
Road tax is about 1/2 the rate it should be.  Real rate is about 4 c/mile. 100 mpg e =$4/gal e tax=12 cent/kwh.  If the electric car gets 200 mpg in city, then tax should be $8/gal e while in city.  Tesla Roadster gets 144 mpg e?  4x1.44=$5.76/gal e =17 c/kwh.  Solar 5? =22 c/kwh
If you go from 25 mpg to 100 mpg, the fuel tax has to go up by 4 x to cover the cost of roads.  If the car gets 100 mpge, it requires an electricity tax cost of 6 c/kwh.  At 2 cents/mile, fuel tax is $2/gal e.  $2/33.7=$0.06/kwh.  Real tax to cover road costs should be twice that
The same thing happens with the grid "tax" or costs as it does the road tax or use tax.  Once the cost of fuel gets low enough and the efficiency high enough, the "road tax" of grid or road becomes a large fraction of costs, whereas before fuel/electricity is a small fraction.
If the grid is 6 c/kwh and the value of intermittent electricity is 2 c/kwh, total would be 8 c/kwh....x 37=$2.96/gal e.  If the cost of wind or PV is 5 c/kwh and grid = 6 that makes $11 c/kwh.  x 37= $4/gal e.  At 5 without grid?  $1.85/gal e.  Remove grid, make at home, good...
The problem with any grid based NH3 transfer or credit is, again, the cost of transmission, which some say is 6-7 c/kwh, which destroys the market for remote made NH3 and credits.  1.1 x 33.7 = 37.  times this by electricity cost and you get gal e cost.  $0.02 x 37=$0.74 c/gal e.

Building new cars and tractors uses a lot of energy.  By using electro-fuels you save the energy (CO2) needed to make a piece of equipment that seldom gets used but is needed.  Banning combustion forces the old to be junk and thus raises CO2 by needing new equipment.

How then does my engine fit into this new grid with NH3?  It is central to it because it can use NH3 and 5 other fuels, thus allowing owners to use lower cost fuel when NH3 supplies are low.   It will take time to develop NH3 markets and fossil fuels will compete against NH3...&gt;
Constant devices can store large amounts of NH3 and sell it when wind/solar fails to produce the needed supply of NH3 required to run vehicles during long winters..  This provides a revenue source outside of the grid and time shifting of grid loads to high demand times/seasons.
All variable machines are then not needed on the grid.  Only constant devices and NH3 as the variable.  Many large plants can be used and temporary excess supply from constant devices absorbed in the storage of NH3, which can be sold later at higher prices when demand spikes.
Intermittent sources like wind and solar should be independent from the grid and make NH3 for use in vehicles where oil is now used.  Thus, they compete with oil as well as the grid via the NH3 made by excess power on the grid.  Simplify the grid with only constant and NH3....&gt;
Constant power devices compete against constant power devices.		Intermediate devices like wind and solar compete with constant grid devices like Nuclear, Coal and Nat Gas combined cycle via NH3 and not via the grid.  The true value of intermediate is in NH3, not grid.
The problem is that each of the suppliers have large fixed costs and  long investment periods.  They will not be willing to be up and down on  price, nor risk shut-down due to clean up end costs.  This then forces long term contracts and voids potential innovation in lower costs.
Whether you use Nuclear, Coal, or Natural Gas (combined cycle), NH3 should be the the throttle to take up demand between supply and grid instantaneous demand.  Each should be able to provide power at a constant power and compete, with NH3 taking up the load variance.
Fuel/power go up as power gets less, and cost of capital (interest) is still the same regardless of power output.  A device making no power costs the same payments as one that is full power.  How then to run the grid and get competition and zero carbon?  Nuclear in excess + NH3.
A variable device can run at partial power.  If it runs at 1/2 power, do you give it a premium for the unused capacity?  Costs for fuel to run a device at low power go up per unit power.  A PW 6A turbo, for example, uses 2x fuel/power at 1/3 power and wear is close to full power.
I can have competition between two devices that are both constant or both variable, but not one that is constant and one that is variable.  This is the central problem of the grid now.  Who gets to make money and at what price?  Cheapest is always at full power, not partial.
....Unless a variable demand were enabled that was in the control of the grid operator or some price signalling.  		By dividing up the grid in constant and variable modes you can compete with common values.  A constant device next to a variable device is not apples to apples.

A variable device with reserve capacity is valuable in a variable demand world.  Without it, the grid would stop, unless..&gt; https://t.co/vJQTCZkS50
Think of NH3 as a liquid battery you can pump into your car quickly.  		Think of Li-ion as a solid battery that has to be part of the car to charge, or that must be exchanged with another battery to use the car while charging.  		Both take time to "charge" before use.
The entire concept of electric cars is silly at best and will fail the company that does it.  Why?  Flow.  Liquids flow.  Batteries do not.  Time = money.  The storage means has to "charge" out of sight, out of mind.  Removing a battery is not valid.  Removing/filling a fuel is.
A battery has a massive (pun intended) disadvantage versus NH3 due to the solid vs liquid nature of the storage means.  Battery is solid.  NH3 is liquid.  One is heavy to move.  One can be pumped and no loading is needed.  Liquid is much better than solid for energy due to flow.
The charger and battery or fuel maker and fuel  needs to be separate from the car so that the slow process of "charging" can be done while the car is being used.  Making NH3 takes time and is like charging a battery.  It is limited by current and size, just like a battery.
Why were some thinking about exchanging out a battery?  Because it takes time to charge a battery.  Time = money.  Charge the battery on a simple stand and let the rest of the car do something valuable.  NH3 does this inherently.  The fuel maker is a charger.  The NH3 = battery.
What is the true cost of an electric cars?  That depends on how much your time is worth and how much the sitting car's time is worth.  If you have an AI car that can make money while driving around, it can't while charging.  Silly concept!  Time = money.  This is why NH3 is KEY!
If you have two professional people at $50/hr sitting in Tesla car waiting to charge a car for 1 hour, it costs $100 in time.  80 kwh x $0.12 /kwh = $9.6 in fuel, but $100 in time.  Actual cost of electricity is 109.6/80= $1.37/kwh.  1.37/.12=11.4 = stupid silly nonsense ....&gt;
An electric car takes too long to charge and as such has an opportunity cost of time for the driver which vastly exceeds the cost of the "fuel" or electricity being absorbed.  NH3 is just like gasoline, quick and simple, in and out, with minimal time costs, unlike electric cars.
The nice thing about NH3 as a demand device is that it does not have tires, brakes, seats, insurance costs, that are not of note to grid services.  It is only a demand device and as such cheap to buy and use per demand use, unlike a car or smart appliance.  Key point!
By introducing NH3 as the variable demand, NO SMART GRID is needed and neither is expanded transmission capacity or variable devices.  Using cars as demand devices is absurd due to their nature as useless while unused as vehicle.  All the tires, brakes, motor etc are held captive
Current grids have many machines to deal with the variable demand.  Smart grid is a way to unload demand when supply is short.  Turning on and off power generation devices affects their efficiency and controlling customer's demand makes silly the concept of a on demand grid.
A constant power device (coal and nuclear) is not as flexible as a device that can vary in power from low to high.  When the variable device is running at low power, is it paid MORE per kwh?  It should due to fixed capital costs and reserve it has available as stand-by.
Below, I restricted grid to 100% nuclear, which is NOT needed.  		Two key issues		1) CONSTANT (base load) vs VARIABLE (any power setting) power	2) Intermittent vs on demand.  		Grid now has little to no price or value signals to these issues, therefore no market can exist.

Once nuclear can be used for NH3 production as well as a grid source, they can expand into all the markets that oil now has via NH3.  This is HUUUUUGE for nuclear and would allow large volume manufacture of nuclear power plants and thus competition in nuclear power systems.
Depending on the price of fossil fuels, the price of NH3 would be ideally be supply and demand driven.  Wind/solar/and other renewables would MAKE NH3 and sell it as fuel.  The grid would do the same.  This would allow many times more nuclear power than just the grid!  Volume N.
If the entire grid were 100% nuclear and constant in power, the rate for retail would have to be set fixed as there is no competition, basically as it now is.  		The grid then can compete with all other NH3 makers and systems by making NH3 for general use.  Unlimited expansion!

With a fixed nuclear grid price set low at 8-9 c/kwh, the competition then becomes Nuclear to NH3 vs independent wind/solar to NH3.  This NH3 can be used in houses, cars, trucks, boats, airplane, factories and more.  At $1.68 /gal, that is ~ 5 c/kwh, which is industrial rates.

Cost of wind, for example, is driven by the cost of the transmission.  By uncoupling from grid and making NH3 only, the wind can be at least 1/2 cost of current.  No inverters would be needed also.  No grids either.  Make remotely, store in tanks, ship to markets.
Any variable and intermittent renewable sourcet needs to be "processed" or disciplined by going to NH3 as storage fuel for vehicles, which are intermittent.  This offline use of renewables allows them to be built for much less costs due to no need to conform to grid frequency.

Again, this is how to ideally get to zero carbon.		Renewables make NH3 only.  This takes the junk power off line.  NO inverters.		Nuclear power is ABOVE peak evening load over base of x (base) at 1.5-2x of power.  		NH3 making is deals with x to 1.5x power variable in daily cycle

In essence, with NH3, nuclear can have 2-3 times MORE power than as a traditional base load, and with NH3 NO turbines, Diesels, or Nat Gas are needed to maintain Voltage and frequency.  Just set at 1.5-2+ (depending on NH3 demand in vehicles) and let NH3 be the variable....&gt;
NH3 can be made and stored for weeks or months, whereas an electric car has to be charged on demand.  This then forces some fractional level of traditional base load, with turbines taking up base to peak loads.  This uses up NH3 for grid support and not car/truck/airplanes.
The nice thing about NH3 over electric cars is the storage nature of fuel and how NH3 then can allow a constant excess level of nuclear power that exceeds the peak load of grid.  If base load is X, peak load might be 1.5 x, and 0.5 difference can be in NH3 making.  Scheduling...&gt;

With 8 motors, and the ability to run on just 2, the airplane can have a motor failure and continue to fly with the motor on the opposite side shut off.  This will be a "normal" operation if desired.  This allows a flight to continue where it would otherwise have to stop.
Since the system is made up of many motors and parts that are the same, they can be taken out one by one and exchanged.  This allows the airplane to be used while each part is zero timed/overhauled.    This avoids costly down time during scheduled maintenance.
With an extra motor, the airplane can be overhauled one motor at a time and still remain in use.  Take one out, put in spare, keep flying.  Do the overhaul and swap out next motor until all have been done.  Swap takes 30 minutes or less.  No down time for airplane.  Swap = key.
If you don't have fuel costs now nor engine costs, you can fly for "free" until the maintenance comes due.  The question then is the maintenance costs and intervals.  Due to the nature of the engine, it can be overhauled in piece wise.  Buy an extra motor and swap it out.....&gt;

Once you have the g CO2/kw-h for each machine + fuel at efficiency you know what it costs in CO2 to get the electricity.  Then divide that by the car efficiency and compare that to actual power for speed and distance.  Got that?
To figure what each fuel would make in g CO2/kw-h all you do is take the 100% efficiency value below (Diesel 250.2) and divide it by the actual efficiency.  Diesels worked well are around 42% at best.  250.2/.42= 595.7 g CO2/kw-h.  Coal 353/.38=930 and so on.
EIA data for CO2lbs/million BTU.  Gasoline = 115000 BTU=33.7 kw-h	Conversion factor to g/kw-h is 1.5511 ,100%	Coal 205-228 = 318-354 g/kw-h	Diesel 161.3 = 250.2  g/kw-h	Gasoline 157.2 = 243.8  g/kw-h	Propane 139 =215.6  g/kw-h	Nat Gas 117 = 181.5  g/kw-h		https://t.co/gZnE0Y3BTw

A free energy machine only cuts out the fuel costs of operating the machine, but does not cut out the operating  and maintenance costs.  Any "free energy" machine will, of course, cost you MORE money to BUY than a non free energy machine in a "free" market.  You pay either way.
Two kinds of costs to use a machine.  Operating costs and maintenance costs.  		Operating costs are known costs, like fuel, oil, tires, brakes, etc.		Maintenance costs are uncertain or unexpected, such as overhauls, failed part, damaged panel, etc.  Stuff happens, fix it....&gt;
So, the cost of a "free energy" machine is the life cycle costs, X price/Y years, plus the average yearly maintenance costs Z.  		So, X/Y + Z is the cost of "free energy" as it were, whether from my system or Nikola Tesla's mythical machine suppressed by "them" or whomever....&gt;
The question is, what would Tesla's "free energy" machine cost you to maintain it?  Clearly something, as everything breaks down and needs repairs.  My system, once paid for, also has a cost of maintenance.  Add in the life cycle costs.  Buy for X, lasts for Y years, X/Y= cost..&gt;

A word about maintenance....  Due to the design and distributed nature, each motor can be held in a hand, removed easily and worked on at a common table.  No stand or special hoist is needed.  This allows easy overhaul.  Redundant motors allow partial engine failure with power.
Most of the advantages are NOT found on electric motor systems.  This is not an old stinky gasoline/Diesel engine that is noisy.  The engine is as quiet as an electric motor, or can be made loud if wanted during high power.  This allows the "feel" of power found in old engines.
One last advantage I forgot to mention.  It has internal electrical heating which allows the engine to run on battery power at a reduced power should such be needed.  The battery size can vary as needed, but energy is not via electric motors, but can be if one is needed.
Below I mention some of the advantages new engine offers not found in other new or old engines.  These features and more are what is needed to make a "flying car" as it were.  We don't have "flying cars" due to the lack of needed engine technology and vehicle designs.

You can add power to car, dolly or trailer.  Up to you.  Each has advantages.  Can change out if needed.  Plug and play.  Yes, a combustion engine that is plug and play....  Read that 1000 times.  This ain't your Daddy's Diesel engine....
Power can be added to the trailer too.  Instead of a power dolly, put the power in the trailer too.  The trailer engine system stays with the trailer and runs the power needs when camping.  Trailer wheels provide power to move added weight.
By adding 4 more engine in car (200 HP more, 50 each), and 2-4 in dolly (100-200 HP), the car goes from 200 HP to 500-600 HP to tow trailer.  Plenty of power.  Done towing, remove dolly and 4 motors.  Back to 200 HP.  Could leave 4 extra in car too.   Same economy.  How?  Discuss
The engine can also allow "power dollies" to pull large trailers.  The car can have a simple hitch and the dolly does the work of tongue load and added power for trailer.  You could also add motors to car plus power dolly.  From 4 motors in car, to 8 in car, and 2-4 dolly....&gt;
Say you want balanced power front and back.  Put two front and two rear.  No problem.  Want more power?  Add two front and two back.  Now have twice the power, but SAME economy.  Understand?
Say someone likes rear drive better than front drive.  OK, move motors from the front to the back.  Put 4 in back to burn rubber, and 1 up front for snow driving.  Now you can "drag race" with smoking tires, yet drive with front wheel drive in snow.  Easy to customize.
Why have "power slots" in car engine.  Let's say someone wants an economy car with all wheel drive.  Ok.  Front has 3 motors, back has 1.    		You install a 4 slot drive front and back.  You leave out 1 motor in front and three in back.  3 front, 1 back.  Upgrade is simple.  Add.
Understand that old engines are custom to the product, whereas my engine system can be added to like memory in a computer.  Want 1000 HP in Corvette, just add more.  Not a big deal.  Have "memory slots" (Power slots) to add or take away power just like computers have....&gt;

@nickraaum An Otto cycle is considered a constant heat addition cycle.  HCCI is the best case of this.  All the heat is done at TDC.  In Diesel, fuel is added as the piston goes down keeping pressures constant.  NH3 needs an "constant temperature" expansion to remain 700-1500K in burn.
@nickraaum I am suggesting that thermodynamics is a path function.  How you get there makes a massive difference.  My engine attempts to run the path to gather the most and allow different fuels and solar thermal injection (hot water).  The device is key to path(s).  Lots of cycles....

To make NH3 work, the ignition temps are higher than Diesel and it is hard to spark.  Gasoline is used to spark in Otto engine to get NH3 to burn and Diesel is used to get NH3 to burn in Diesel engine.  Both need added injection and alteration to make work.  Not simple....

The effect of CO2, like closing a window, occurs in the first 20-80 ppm.  It finds a new equilibrium and temperature and adding MORE insulation (CO2) to the wall section/segment does little to "trap" heat in the building.  Heat just goes around it via other paths still open.

The atmosphere is like a house with half the walls in place.  The attenuation of any GHG is like a wall.  More = insulation.  Re-radiation to ground causes the heat to find another path via frequencies not attenuated, and the heat escapes.  Adding insulation to a wall does zero.
Why does heating occur only when the last window and door is closed?  Because convection currents become stronger through the remaining openings to balance heat, canceling out most of the the effect of closing an incremental door.  When the last opening is closed, heating occurs.
Try this experiment.  Open ALL windows and doors of house 100% and turn heater on.  Then close one at a time.  Does the house get warmer by an equal percentage of the window or door area?  No!  Why?  Convection!  Not until the last window is closed will heating occur. Understand?
When you open a window in house, the heating effect goes away and does not occur unless the convection currents are blocked by windows and doors.  Even one window kills the effect, let alone half the house.  Closing each window does not heat more and more due to convection....&gt;
In 1820 Fourier basically stated that for a greenhouse effect to occur ALL of the spectrum had to be attenuated, not just part.  There cannot be any holes for the heat to get out.  Clearly, IR attenuation graphs show that heat is not fully attenuated, therefore AGW = false.
When heat re-radiates down to the ground, which is like a pool of energy, the heat is transferred to colder areas due to the natural flow of heat.  The cold areas are cold because radiation went to space.  The heat is supplied by the re-radiated heat to the ground....out it goes.
On a cold day, open all the windows.  Is the house warm?  NO!  Close more and more windows.  Even if one window remains open, the house remains cold.  The same applies to Infrared radiation (IR).  Unless ALL (!) the spectrum is absorbing fully (100%) you don't have a greenhouse.

@Lumberist 42 US gallons/barrel.  3.78 liters/gal.  $42.69/42/3.78= $0.26/liter.  Lots of taxes and mark up in fuel...
If you have six 10 gallon tanks, one tank can be known fuel quality.  Ground test new fuel for performance.  OK?  Then takeoff.  The known fuel is used for initial takeoff.  Test out new fuel in each tank in air to see if all goes well as second check to ground tests.  No crashes
The FAA requires 30 minutes for VFR and 45 minutes for IFR flight.  If the airplane burns 10 gal/hr, that means you must have 5 gallons (VFR) or 7.5 gallons (IFR) left at landing.  If tanks are 60 gallons (like C-172) that means about 16% of the fuel needs to be known.  6 tanks.
With many motors, the new fuel is put into empty tanks.  The full tank with known good fuel could be a 1 hour tank, for example, that meets FAA rules.  Takeoff, switch to tanks with new fuel and run on a few motors to see if fuel works normally.  If bad, return and land. No crash
Another issue is the engine system MUST have multiple engines and fuel paths so that one fuel type or fill up won't take the airplane out.  Fuel quality control is not always certain at some car fuel stations. Fuel system design must account for issues including water for safety.

The biggest issue is that the current grid is a large monopoly run by well connected people.  It is NOT market based at the core.  It is managed.  But what happens when it is forced to become market based?  Lawsuits, technology, etc., can change it all, which will change the ROI.
If you invest in capital that has a high maintenance and low life cycle like wind and PV, you will end up making nothing come time to replace the parts.  You basically eat your seed capital. This is where my technology focuses in on, the cost of maintenance and longevity.
People make the mistake of using TODAY's price of energy and not understanding what the future supply from many people will do to the price.  If suddenly everybody can produce excess fuel, what would be the price of fuel?  Answer: based on labor input and capital costs.
When the technology goes to allowing everybody to produce energy, the value of energy in a market will be very very low due to supply.  Some will invest and provide fuel to neighbors and some will just buy fuel.  The competition will drive prices down to low wages and ROI.

The belief that "without oil nothing happens" will be shown to be wrong with my engine system and NH3 maker and storage.  All the "energy" investments such as wind and PV will not pan out and will be of little value due to high costs of maintenance.  No need for large batteries.
After 1 month of considering NH3 as a fuel and how to make it work, the new goal is to enable NH3 so that a house system can provide fuel back up to solar year round for house, and fuel to drive vehicles during the year. This fuel is stored in a propane type tank.  No oil needed
The reason to go with NH3 is mostly to be able to make fuel without the need of buying it from some central source.   In the event of some disaster or emergency, having independent fuel source is key.  If the grid goes down this system can still provide fuel for house + seaplane.

The reason "hybrids" were even considered is that IC engines can consume  2 times MORE fuel when ran at none optimum ranges.  Peak efficiency is  usually at around 3/4th throttle for an Otto engine, with a best range  in the 2000-2200 rpm. It varies. https://t.co/pEN5kIzqNZ
Most people don't realize that an any motor/engine, IC, electric or hydraulic, varies depending on load.  Each has a BSFC curve that maps how efficient it is at different torque and RPM settings.  They are NOT constant in the efficiencies.   Peak efficiency is only one setting...

@TomRhyno @HeisenbergErwin @JaggerMickOZ @RegimeChangeBC @AltUS_ARC @Jerbivore @LifeIsThermal @NoelTurner194 @BrunoPresents @GillesnFio @Mathenaut @tigerzntl @conradgoehausen @Captbobdad @drwaheeduddin @brandondaly2018 @MamaMac_ @Sci_Resistance @ClaireNewton79 @GeorgePembroke @StealthFlyBy @kevpluck @d_e_mol @davestewart3 @hllsen @HughAbercrombi3 @Lulzmouse @boggywood @CymaticWave @beegeerose @Carablades @tjipkoopmans @JWSpry @FriendsOScience @GetMyGist @SylviaD32911201 @bmartus5 @LeeLafferty4 @tan123 @realDonaldTrump @InfoWarsChannel @BarrettBrownLOL The difficult thing is to get LOW power in a large engine.  You see this clearly in a Corvette that gets 25 mpg highway, but 12 city.  It should get at least 50 mpg city if it maintained highway efficiency, not 12.  This is what most people don't see. Somewhat like a Lycoming, the engine can have each motor or "jug" removed, then overhauled without taking the entire engine apart.  But unlike a Lycoming, it is not a piston ring fit issue with oil, pistons and rods...mess.  Pull it out, plug in new.
The maintenance of the engine should also be much less in cost and time due to the part nature of the engine.  Each motor can be removed, worked on, and replaced without having to deal with a heavy engine, hoist and work stand.  Just work on any regular table, replace.

This understanding of the need to land on a road completely changed my seaplane design and allowed me to get out of the box I was in.  It lead me to a new type of engine that is unlike jets or old piston crank engines, thus leading to solving energy, water, and so many things...&gt;
I debated people on Homebuilt-airplanes web page for almost a year about landing on roads.  It was an idea I had and all debaters were against it, which told me I was right.  Being able to land on road drives ALL of the design, especially the engine and characteristics needed.
The entire problem is analogous to climbing the corporate latter.  Climbing to the top of something you don't want to be at is a waste of time.  Knowing where to put the latter is very time consuming and difficult.  For Ex, knowing you have to land on the road is key to all.....&gt;
I started out just wanting to cut the fuel load to allow me to take my wife to Hawaii.  Step by step I realize there is a better way IF I change this or that.  This goes on for YEARS as I learn more and more what the real problem is.  Know what the real problem is is 80% of work.
Once of the biggest time consumers is realizing that something won't quite work.  You compromise, thinking that you can buy something off the shelf, to find out that it won't work or will be gone long before production starts.  No off the shelf part can be certified either....&gt;
And when it comes to airplanes, any existing engine company does NOT want their engine in an airplane unless they can charge you 10 times more.   With existing engine, the packaging is all wrong and the weight is much too high.  It all just does NOT work.  Sorry to say it.....&gt;
To build something new in engines, it has to have a major advantage over existing offerings.  There are thousands of engine companies with some small benefit here and there.  Any small thing would require me to scab of of existing firms which don't want me around.....&gt;
Most have some narrow agenda or desire to see something built well before they have a concept that is worth building.  Time after time this happens, where somebody gets an idea and they believe that "if you build it, they will come."  No, that only happens it makes lots of sense.
What I am realizing is that I might have to do this all alone, which is fine.  It may take longer, but in the end I will have a major breakthrough that I would not be able to achieve with help due to politics and diverse interests.  Most just want to bang something out.....&gt;
I am not saying that I have all the bugs worked out.  I am saying that I have a concept that is very promising and worth my own money to invest in.  All the previous concepts fell short of my willingness to invest.  Funny how one thinks when personal money is on the line...&gt;
That 9 years is really only part time and amounts to many concepts that were scrapped as I learned how to better solve the problem of energy.  Nine (9) years is far less compared to the billions of hours spent by other people and companies over the years in solving energy....&gt;

@Brought_to_You Does not matter, my engine system can get us to zero carbon (NH3) in cars, trucks, airplanes, boats, houses, factories and more.  100% carbon out, not because of CO2 but because it will be CHEAPER and independent from oil.  No government work needed except to GET OUT OF WAY!
This step by step process starts with people who have money and eventually works down to lower cost apartments where the landlord supplies fuel to tenants and all cars have new engine and low cost energy.  No scam is needed like with wind/PV solar nonsense.  Just lower costs.
As the savings become real, customers then can look to MORE savings by  purchasing solar panels, and then a NH3 fuel maker.  They see they can use NH3  in car, airplane, boat or house and thus become 100% independent from grid or station fuels.  NH3 then becomes a standard fuel.
The engine allows carbon fuels that now exist and NH3 that could exist in the future.  A NH3 maker COSTS MONEY and therefore requires MORE investment  This investment is enabled by the immediate savings via the engine and can be paid for from those savings.....&gt;
When a building needs heat, it produces electricity, and the waste heat is used or stored for use in the building.  This makes electricity 100% efficient to generate where as now it is 45-60% due to lost waste heat.  Over time we move to NH3 from made NH3 used in house engines.
The reason power is made away from a building is that old piston engines were not efficient enough and turbines were much to big (2000 HP+).  With my engine, this all changes, making combined heat and power viable via Natural Gas which is totally clean.  It is also quiet.
All power to a building should be made at the building to use the waste heat.  By adding in solar, fuel would be used less during sunny days.  By adding in solar thermal store, most of the fuel would be eliminated.  Fuel as back up. 24/7-360 power.  Then NH3 to replace CH4.
If you put the engine in houses/factories/office buildings and only run it off of Natural Gas, for example, you would save the 40-55% by having "combined heat and power.  Short term turbines are 45%.  Combined cycle (slow base load) are 60%.  You would save the waste heat.

Houses and factories is where 50% of CO2 is made.  By having engine in house and factory, the grid will cut CO2 via grid contracts.  Add in solar, solar thermal storage, and then NH3 maker and you get to 100% carbon ASAP.  Not so with wind and PV via electric cars.
With lots of people switching to my engine, you get an immediate 70-80% reduction in CO2 by virtue of the engine alone.  If an entire new car were made that got 200 mpg (possible) then 80-90% of the fuel would be gone.  In semi trucks 50-65% gone.  This then moves to house....&gt;
By NOT having carbon taxes, the path to zero carbon is downhill all the way.  Start with my engine.  The person gets 75% off fuel costs to drive places via extra efficiency.  He then invests in house fuel maker, solar and engine for house to become independent.  Then station....&gt;
Simple math.  Guy uses gasoline car.  25 mpg.  New engine in car.  100 mpg.  4:1.  He uses gasoline and cuts his bill by 75%.  Car can also use Propane or NH3, but both are more expensive now and rare to find.  Over time NH3 become available from house, station, then airport.
To get to NH3 you need a way to use it.  My engine is that way.  But until NH3 is available, the engine MUST use other fuels from the three sources of fueling: 1) house, 2) station, 3) airport.  Until enough engines can use NH3, nobody will supply NH3.  Chicken and egg problem.
Remember, if you jack the cost of carbon fuels up via taxes, you will LENGTHEN the time it takes to get to zero carbon, NOT shorten the time.  Why?  Because it takes away the savings of new engine (4x less costs) which then slows the market for NH3 as option.  Understand?

I started with what I needed in an engine, the characteristics needed, package size, weights and so forth.  Most engineers just apply what is to an application and never do the needed work in discovering the "whys" of the engine.  This is what sets me apart from all others.

People have lost hope in IC engines from a lack of ability to think outside of the box and to understand what is needed.  The most valuable part of this engine development process is the understanding of what is needed, not just the actual engine concept.  Few see this....&gt;
Just as the Jet engine and the Piston engine are different in the structure and processes, my engine is different than both engines.  Why?  Because you can't get to the needed power characteristics with either the old piston engines or the old jet engines.  Won't work.  Key.
You cannot take a piston crank engine and make real advances due to the nature of the system.  You have to create a NEW system that allows the needed elements to be express in the device without all of the negative restrictions found in today's Diesel and Gasoline engines.
As you can see with my few comments here about Diesel and Gasoline engines, there is a LOT of room to advance the internal combustion engine.  In fact I would say we are only 10-20% of the way, whereas my engine is 90%.  Last month it was only 80% of the way (no NH3) back then..&gt;
People don't realize just how much "drag" a gasoline engine has.  Go down a steep hill in low gear and turn around and drive the SAME speed up the hill.  Your engine will struggle to go up as fast as it does go down with only engine drag.  On flat roads that drag is still there.
Perhaps the biggest advantage a Diesel has is in the ability to heavily boost intake pressures with turbos.  This allows a wide range of power, yet a good low power efficiency not found in gasoline engines.  This High boost is where most of the "torque" comes from.
In contrast, a gasoline engine uses a throttle to cut power, which in turn lowers the effective expansion ratio and increases pumping losses, and thus the efficiency.  In part load, this throttle effect can double the fuel consumption.  Hence, 20% highway, 10% city efficiency...&gt;
One of the reasons semi trucks use diesel engine is the part load efficiency of a Diesel is better than that of a gasoline engine.  For ex, a 450 hp semi needs about 250 hp to drive at 65 mph.  At 250 hp the engine is still efficient, but at 75 hp around town the BSFC is 2x....&gt;
Adding fuel as the expansion occurs is NOT as efficient as adding heat in a fixed volume as a gasoline engine theoretically is supposed to do, but it does add an option that allows for efficient running and hard running when needed for short duration.  Duty cycle is key.
One of the reasons a Diesel has "torque" over a gasoline engine is that fuel can be added after the initial combustion, whereas gasoline engine traditionally have one preset mix of air and fuel.  This adding of fuel allows the pressure to be maintained as the expansion occurs.
Moreover, the engine has to be able to have the fuels MIXED and it must be able to adapt to changing fuel types dynamically when fuel separates in the tank and the pick up draws on one type over another.  Fill with one fuel, then later another.  Should not matter.  Key.
Ask why can't current engines use gasoline or Diesel?  There are many reasons, too long for twitter, but until you have an engine that can use any of the common fuels, including propane and NH3, you have an engine that is not adaptive to fuel needs, and therefore NOT VALID....&gt;

Fuel cells are also full of problems and require buffering via batteries to allow peak power to motors.  You see this in the Nikolos semi truck that uses H2 fuel cells.  The fuel cell becomes a low power battery charger with all the negative issues found in battery systems.
The reason we use "hybrids" is because an electric motor needs one type of "fuel" (electricity) and in a narrow spec.  It cannot use the 6 types of fuel now used in transportation, nor NH3.  To get to NH3 a bridge is needed allowing any fuel, thus eliminating range anxiety.
The big problem with using electrics and fuel cells with NH3 is the purity of the fuel needed and singularity.  A NH3 fuel cell cannot use all types of fuels found in house (propane, Nat Gas, NH3), fuel station (gasoline, Diesel, propane, E85), or airport (Jet fuel, 100 LL).
@ALIATISFUND Instead of turning off the renewables to maintain grid voltage and frequency, the NH3 makers absorb excess, thus becoming the "throttle" of the grid.  This NH3 then can be used in mobile apps.  My engine enables NH3 much better than old Otto engines due to 3x range and features.
@ALIATISFUND Yes, correct, it does NOW, but there is a way to make NH3 via electricity.  The idea is to make NH3 with excess wind and solar during times of over production by renewables and store it in NH3 to be used when batteries run out (short time) and renewables are lacking during night.
What is the cost of a battery driven car over my technology?  Around  8-16 times. In an airplane?  50-100 times more....  Weight is key in the air.  Useful load fraction is terrible for battery driven vehicles, and NO active drag reduction or deice for free.  Future is flying!
@signup55765001 @RealSaavedra Speaking of sheep, CO2 cannot effect temperature because the attenuation of IR is not complete....  In other words, a gate half open cannot trap half the sheep.  The theory was said by Fourier in 1820 to be wrong and is still wrong becuase "the gate of IR is half open to space."
Sure, you can run a car on a battery, but at what costs?  The main cost is the battery and the extra weight.  Also, electrics don't work on air like my engine will/does, nor does it do thermal as by product (free).  This is key to 2-4 times better economy over battery few see.
An accumulator does NOT supply continuous power, just like a battery does not.  It is a spring that allows time for the engine to start up and supply the large power needed.  It allows instant response for small amounts, but not continuous supply.  Understand? Key concept.
A battery is like having an "accumulator" in a hydraulic circuit.  It allows a small amount of energy to be ready without having to run the engine/pump with all the overhead.  The accumulator gives the instant response ability while waiting and allows the engine to be turned off.
Although a battery will cost you $4/gal to use it, it makes sense if you only need a small and constant amount to run efficient electronics that use very little energy.  The mistake is in assuming ALL energy should travel via the battery because electronics use it.  Not wise.
There is a place for batteries, so don't misunderstand.  They are best when the power is below 1 kw or where the engine becomes inefficient.  Charging a cell phone via larger battery is better than running engine due to the small amount needed.  This is where people get lost....
Again, what is the cost of electricity at noon on a clear sky day?  ZERO? You have to PAY to get rid of it if you don't have a way to store it.  NH3 is the "battery" of the future, not LI-ion.  Current LI-ion is twice the cost per unit energy store.  So why bother?
In any truly market based economy, when the supply is large, the price drops.  When wind, PV panels and Nuclear all conspire together, they will need to make NH3 to be cost effective.  When houses makes NH3, this then will drive the cost of NH3 to less than $1-2/gal e or less.
The key to getting off oil is to use the renewables ALL the time.  This will be done via NH3, which will then be used in my engine (or similar).  My engine will allow 2-4 times BETTER fuel economy than an electric car and thus best use of renewables by far.  Energy cost &gt; 0.
Since NH3 will be the fuel of the future to bridge when renewable don't work, it will require the use of fuel cells, combustion turbines or engines of some kind.  My engine eliminates the need for multiple systems.  Understand?  This is key to lower costs.  One system, not 2-4.
In order for the grid to function in the future it will need to make NH3 to bridge when renewables are not available.  Batteries will NOT be enough.  The excess power during high renewable production periods will be converted into NH3 and used in combustion.  Understand?  KEY.
When someone advocates wind and PV panel renewable energy, they are screaming that it does not work.   $Trillions have been spent on wind and PV panels and they are still MORE expensive with volume.  This tells you they are NOT the correct solution.  My technology will be less $.

Without the ability to use other fuels, the price of NH3 will be all over the place and making a car dependent on NH3 alone would make costs very unstable.  The same would apply to electric cars if we had market electricity prices every minute changing.  My engine is key to this.
Just as the price of Propane goes up in the winter and down the lowest in August, the price of NH3 will go up and down depending on the supply from renewable sources.  This will take time to develop a stable markets for NH3.  My engine's ability to use other fuels will be key.
The cost of NH3 production will drive the price of the floor of electricity costs.  If a catalyst is found that allows 10% energy to make NH3 instead of 100%, this will change the floor price of electricity.  This will change during seasons, just like the price of corn does.
In essence, the real throttle to the grid will be NH3 production that turns on when the price of electricity drops below some cost determined by the supplier.  Excess wind and solar then makes NH3 when prices drop below around 3 cent/kw-hr, or some price as a function of NH3 cost
What if wind and solar are at the max during the day, what does the nuclear power plant do?  Who takes priority?  Wind?  Solar?  Nuclear?  and at what price?  Positive or negative?  Who decides?  Have to be fair, right?  How?  How do you get your investment back?  Hence, NH3.
In a market based grid, during the day with lots of solar, the price of electricity will drop.  At some point solar will have to be shut off, but who gets turned off and what is the price of electricity during the day with excess capacity?  Welcome to the future grid reality.
With demand during the day being met in excess by PV panels, the electricity during the night will have to rely on turbines, wind and other sources.  Price of night electricity could go way up, exactly when cars  are being charged.  Going to get expensive!

The underlying problem is who is allowed to produce and make money?  In a market the lowest cost provider supplies the product, but the grid is NOT done this way now, but soon will have to be.  With so many houses using their PV panels for electricity during the day, demand zero.
When you have more supply than demand, the price goes to zero, but how to shut off supply when it is not wanted?  You go to negative pricing!  Those machines (nuclear) who can't shut off will be charged more negative rates as PV panels start to feel the pain and turn off.
What will happen to solar when there is a 5 minute bid and ask pricing for electricity during the day, or even a 1 minute or 10 second price?  The bid and ask becomes the throttle of the grid, turning on and off machines according to set points a suppler is willing to produce at.
One of the reasons we have such a mess on the grid now is that there are no price signals that reflect the true cost of electricity during the day relative to supply.  Supply and demand is NOT market based, but contract based, which forces distortions of use.  This will change.
One of the problems with electrical cars is the variability of the TRUE cost of electricity in the moment.  During a sunny day, electricity  could be zero price but high costs, and during the night 40  c/kw-hr in cost but less in price.  With bid and ask pricing costs will vary.

The point is that when true costs of road travel is considered, including tires, brakes, insurance risks, delays, hotels and more, the real and only solution becomes to fly the cargo, not drive it.  Somewhere around 200 mph seems about right, or 4x current average truck speed.
If the 40 c/mile savings were added to current ground fuel costs of 47 cent/mile for a truck ($3.3/gal/7 mpg= .47c/m) for a total of 87 cent/mile, then the speed would be 298 mph at 25,000 feet or 6x ground speeds.
If true costs were had for trucks, the road tax would be around 24 cent/mile.  Add in tires at 8 cents/mile, brakes at 2 and road stuff at 6...total ~ 40 cent/mile just because you are on the road.  If Fuel = $2/gal, then flying semi speed at 40 c/m = 202 mph.  Like FREE FUEL !
Road tax is a clear example of how distorting market prices leads to wrong solutions.  Tax rates have not gone up since 1993 and inflation has doubled costs.  Real costs are partially carried by the income tax instead of actual costs, thus hiding costs of road travel.

So, a trucker makes 45 c/mile on the ground.  At an average speed of 50 mph, that makes $22.5/hr.  If the fuel costs were equal (50 c/m), and flew at 184 mph, the trucker/pilot would make $82.8/hr. (184/50 x 22.5=82.8).  Fly 1400 hrs/year....$115,000 vs $45,000 for 100k ground.
At 15% of power, 184 mph, the power would be 907 HP and 50 c/m on $3/gal fuel.  If you could get fuel at $1/gal vs 3, Cruise would be 319 mph for 50 c/m costs.  319/50 mph for ground = 6.4 x for same fuel cost/mile.  Trucker would make 6.4 times more/hr. $22.5/hr ground x 6.4=144
At 200 mph and 25,000 feet, the semi would need about 20% of power.  RPM would be around 1/2 peak speed for quiet cruise.  Mpg would be ~5.  Slow to 185 mph and get 6 mpg just like road truck at 55 mph.  No traffic.  No worry.  Just watch the autopilot and enjoy the ride.

So, I got into a discussion on wind mills.  The question is what is the maintenance cost/kw-hr?  Some say 1-2 cent/kw-hr.  Some say costs are 10.0 cent/kw-hr actual.  Does anybody have real figures?

It is the new favorite of AGW people because it has no carbon (NH3...no C in it, see...).  It has potential to enable solar fuel generation from homes/buildings, thus making fuel.  Might be $1-2/gal e, less than gasoline...lower costs....

@michaelfreeman @Jali_Cat @SenSchumer They are called Dykes....LOL
This ability to use many types of fuel will be important to low costs as fuel types changes over time to perhaps NH3 and electricity, or even some other fuels other than gasoline and Diesel, and even more so with airplanes.
With electric cars, one cannot "fuel" them with many types of fuels and when they go empty, damage can occur,  Not so with engine.  A small bottle of fuel can get it going.  One can use a public bus to go fetch fuel, but not so with batteries. This fuel ability is key to future.
The key is that this engine systems in house and cars can use other fuels other than NH3 should NH3 not be available or the system does not produce enough for family needs.  Propane, gasoline, Diesel, Jet A, 100 LL, or even E85, Methanol, Ethanol could also power the house/cars.
If you can get an engine system that is 24/7, 365 that runs 100% on solar and uses that solar to fuel your cars and bridge cloudy days via NH3, why would you want grid power at current rates, especially at European rates of 30+ cents/kw-hr?
Power must be 24/7 regardless of the weather or climate.  Some years are cloudy, some are not.  It varies.  The problem with batteries is they don't allow charging or filling of fuel when they run out.  Fuel is needed to bridge seasons due to storage size.
Each of the factors of engine, solar panels, solar thermal store, NH3 maker and tank size play a roll in allowing independent energy sourcing.  Every year is not the same temperature wise or solar wise, so tolerance is key.  Tanks can be filled easily, allowing tolerance.
If the car and house could interface and allow fuel transfer, the hassle factor of getting fuel would be eliminated during zero solar periods.  If 5 days =100 gallons, a 400 gallon tank, or four 100 gallon tanks in yard would be enough to bridge a month.  Small space.
One 100 gallon tank would be enough if gasoline.  Nh3 needs 3x.  That means 100 gallons of NH3 would last 3.66 days.  By cutting thermal losses, it might go for 5 days/100 gallons, which includes cars, btw.  If the car has 30 gallons, you could fill up car and bring home in car.
How many Gallon equiv of NH3 are needed per day?  		Heating: Assume 216 gal/m.  /30=7.2  (no solar)	30 kw-hr/day = 30/36 =.8  via engine /.6=1.38  	81 miles/day at 200 mpg =.4		Total 7.2+1.4+.4=9/day = 324 kw-hr/day.  	600 lbs/gal.  5400 lbs/day bat.		100 gallon?  100/9=11 days.
But by using a battery you can't ever get to 100% off grid ability.  Why?  Because a battery, like solar thermal storage, has only a limited time of use after which an entire back up generator system would be needed.  You can't bring in fuel or charge remotely or store enough.
Just as batteries are a deferred cost (buy up front, replace later), engine maintenance is the same.  If people don't like counting battery use costs, then my engine on solar then can be zero cost and therefore zero cost for NH3.  So, by going to NH3 you have "free" fuel.
If my engine in car were to use battery power and not NH3, what would be the cost?  $8/gal for battery use.  8/.6= $13.3 or about the same as electric, which is 4 times more than just making NH3.  Battery costs would have to drop by 4 times to make batteries better than NH3.
If engine + solar thermal maintenance were 2.79 cents/kw-hr, NH3 would cost  $2/gal.  Combustion would be 60%, for a cost of 3.33 at wheel.  Twice through batteries is 66% and $8/gal (2x$4/gal bat use).  8/.66=12.  92% electric motor... $13.2 total cost.  		13.2/3.33=3.96
To make NH3 at $6/gal is 8.3 cent/kw-hr (6/36 kw-hr/gal /2 units of electricity input per= 8.3 cents/kw-hr).  With Natural Gas you can make electricity at 5.5 cents/kw-hr from $1/gal Nat Gas, which translates to $3.96/gal. (0.055x2x36=3.96)  Better to just use Nat Gas.
The problem with using batteries is you have to store it in a battery at home, then use that battery to charge the car when it returns at night.  The energy remaining is 66% which means the battery costs you $6/gal (4/.66=6), not 4.  What electricity price is NH3 at $6/gal? ....&gt;
Notice that if I cut out all the house thermal loads by having lots of solar thermal, I still cannot cut out the fuel needed for the car unless batteries or NH3 are used.  Batteries cost $4/gal plus the loss in and out at 81%, which means $5/gal out of the battery.

Moreover, My engine can harvest water, distill water, move air,  move heat to thermal store, and torque a vehicle/trailer wheel group if so designed.  PV panels cannot.  Any excess can be stored via NH3, whereas batteries are very heavy and costly to use.
By going with solar thermal + engine, I can make electricity at about the same rate per area as PV panels, and I get thermal loads added to capture.  That amounts to 4-5 times more energy per panel area that is useful to house/trailer/car/airplane.
My house used 1500 gal/y Nat Gas for heating, and 10800 kw electricity or 300 gal.		300/1800=16.6% (1/6th) of total load is electricity. 		This ratio is close to the amount of electricity and heating able from thermal panels + engine.  PV panel only gets electric part, not heat.
By going with thermal and my engine, you get access to 4 times more energy per unit panel size, and you can use the waste heat from electrical generation to heat/cool building or water.  PV panels use electrical to heat, thus wasting 3 units of 4 potential.  PV panels complex.
The thing that fools people with electricity vs thermal is the focus on electricity.  For example, PV panels are 15%.  A Thermal panel is 60-70% capture of energy.  That is 4+ times more energy.  But to get electricity from thermal you might be 15-20%, just like the PV panel.
So, you say to run it via fuel cells?  Ok, 50%.  2x to make NH3.  2/0.5= 4x  to get electricity from NH3.  You only store 1/4.  		This is poor energy store.  		Hence batteries.  1/0.9 in = 1.11.../0.9 out ...1.23.  or 81% of the energy recovered.  1/0.33= 3.03/.81=3.75 with grid.
If it takes 6.06 units of energy to make 1 unit of NH3, then to get electricity from the NH3 takes 6.06/.33=18.36.  The point here is that running NH3 into inefficient engines is not smart.  My engine is the ONLY valid engine for NH3.  Fuel cells are 50%, hence 2x to make NH3.
What people don't realize is that electricity is not just the energy you get from it, but the energy it took to create it which is wasted at the power plant.  The current grid is about 33%, so it takes 3 units of energy to make one.  If it takes 2 to make NH3 then 2/.33=6.06
With free energy, the cost then is the cost of maintenance to run the engines or wind mills.  Some say wind mills cost 5 cent/kw-hr for maintenance.  .05 x 2 x 36 = $3.6/gal.  Still not even close.
Perspective:  If a 25% efficient engine were used to make NH3 it would take 2/0.25=8.  To make electricity from NH3 would than take 8/0.25=32.  Clearly making NH3 is not smart unless the energy input is nearly free.  In the case of solar thermal, it is "free" from the sun.
If the NH3 maker takes only 10% to convert then 1.1/0.6= 1.833.  1.833/0.6=3.055.  This is the lowest possible energy use of the process.  So, from 3-5 times is used to get one unit of electricity.  Clearly electricity use should be minimized, mostly to LEDs and Computers.
Since it takes 5.55 units of heat energy to make 1 unit of electrical energy from solar thermal to NH3 to electricity, it becomes key to avoid using electrical energy from Nh3 as much as possible to heat or cool buildings, and to use waste heat as much as possible.  Local.
If 2 units of electricity make 1 unit of energy in the form of NH3, and the engine is 60%, then it takes 2/0.6 = 3.33 units of heat energy to get 1 unit of energy in NH3.  To use NH3 in an engine at 60% takes 3.333/0.6 = 5.55 units of heat to get 1 unit of electricity.  5.55:1
If an engine is 60% efficient at generating electricity, like the grid is with a Natural gas combined cycle system, then to get 1 unit of electricity it takes 1/0.6 = 1.66 units of energy.  In other words, 60% is electricity and 40% is waste heat.  Waste heat use is key.

The water thermal store cuts night electrical costs down from 9 c/kwh using NH3 store to 4 cent/kwh on average, and 3 directly.  The hot water store also synergies with water purification and harvest to deal with water use which is a big factor in stand along non grid apps.
With the water store, bridging from day to night occurs 85% of the time with hot water and 15% with NH3 fuel.  The cost then of electricity 85% of the times is 3 cents/kwh and 15% is 9.  (.85 x 3 + .15 x 9) = 3.9 c/kwh average, say 4.  That is 1/3 the cost of grid.  Doable....
If the solar thermal is stored in hot water instead of NH3, the engine is used to make electricity only once, not twice.  Nor is 2x electricity needed.  Solar thermal is then 1 engine, 1 panel and 1 water store or about 3 cent/kwh, not 9-12 via NH3.  Cut costs via water store...
Depending on assumptions and actual costs, the concept of solar to electricity to fuel (NH3) and back to electricity again via engine is competitive when maintenance for engine, solar, and fuel maker are each 1 c/kwh, with fuel maker factor 2:1.  Result is 9 c/kwhr electricity.
If engine maintenance were 1 c/kwh and solar panel was 1, what is the round trip price from solar to electricity to fuel to electricity again?  NH3 factor 2.		((1+1) x2)/.6  + 1 = 7.6 c/kwh.   Add in 1 for fuel maker maintenance and you have 8.6, say 9 c/kwh.  Grid 1st tier.
The round trip price of electricity to fuel to electricity again via engine from solar would be around grid prices at 3 c/kwh for solar and 2 c/kwh maintenance on engine from fuel to electricity with a 2x factor in NH3 maker.  (0.03 x2 / 0.6) +2 = 12.  This is doable.
If your target price for fuel is $2/gal, a little less than gasoline ($2.25/gal no tax), then the cost of electricity would have to be around  3 cent/kw-hr.  (2/33.7/2=0.297). 6 c/kwhr.  /.6=.1.  add in  2 cent maintenance for 12 cent/kwh.

Diesel is a dirty fuel, so it is not preferred.  However, trucks use it now.  Ideally propane would be used in trucks.  Added tanks would allow long range, with gasoline as a backup and Diesel as a second backup.  At the start however, Diesel may be the only option for trucks.
Three main fuels for the engine will be NH3, Propane and Gasoline.  All can be handled as liquid in engine due to them all being under pressure while in tanks.  Diesel, 100 LL and Jet A will be considered last.   Diesel is dirty fuel.  100 LL expensive + lead, Jet A expensive.
Depending on how the NH3 maker is made, some of the heat can be captured and used to heat house.  This is unknown as of now to me.  Making a NH3 is a large project and will be AFTER the engine is running on the other 5 fuels (Propane, Gasoline, Diesel, 100 LL, Jet A).
With engine, the waste heat can be used to heat house.  60% goes to electricity and 40% goes to waste heat.  This is where water comes in.  By buffering the heat in water, it can be drawn out later to maintain house temperatures.  That lowers losses to just 1.1 to 2 times.
